item.title: Life sentence for man who shook girlfriend's five-month-old baby to death
item.content:encoded: Thomas Morgan's "rage-filled attack" left the five-month-old boy with catastrophic injuries.

item.title: 'Jekyll and Hyde' killer guilty of shooting ex-colleague on remote country path
item.content:encoded: Former gamekeeper David Campbell murdered Brian Low in Aberfeldy two years ago then tried to cover his tracks.

item.title: UK government denies Chagos Islands deal is paused, after minister said it was
item.content:encoded: It come after a minister said the UK is discussing "concerns" with the US, after President Trump criticised the deal.

item.title: UK records warmest day of the year as temperatures climb above 18C
item.content:encoded: After a relentlessly wet start to the year the UK has recorded its warmest day of the year as many places bask in the late winter sunshine.

item.title: Household energy bills to fall in April after charges shake-up
item.content:encoded: Changes announced in the Budget mean all energy bills will see some kind of reduction, but it will vary.

item.title: Household energy bills to fall in April after charges shake-up
item.content:encoded: Changes announced in the Budget mean all energy bills will see some kind of reduction, but it will vary.

item.title: Household energy bills to fall in April after charges shake-up
item.content:encoded: Changes announced in the Budget mean all energy bills will see some kind of reduction, but it will vary.

item.title: Starmer promises to look at making student loans 'fairer'
item.content:encoded: Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch said the system had become a "debt trap" for graduates.

item.title: Uefa rejects Benfica appeal over Prestianni ban
item.content:encoded: Gianluca Prestianni will miss the second leg of Benfica's Champions League tie against Real Madrid after Uefa reject the club's appeal against his suspension.

item.title: Trump keeps world waiting on his plans for Iran after State of the Union
item.content:encoded: The next round of talks between the US and Iran in Geneva on Thursday could be decisive in the president's decision-making.

item.title: Man arrested after 'axe carried into mosque'
item.content:encoded: Manchester Central Mosque said the "swift actions of its volunteers" had "contained the situation".

item.title: Man Utd post profit but debt rises to £1.3bn
item.content:encoded: The amount Manchester United owe increases to almost £1.3bn in outstanding transfer fees, rolling credit facility and legacy debt.

item.title: Commons Speaker passed Mandelson flight risk information to police ahead of arrest
item.content:encoded: Sir Lindsay Hoyle tells MPs he was acting "in good faith as is my duty and responsibility" as he felt information was "relevant".

item.title: Is TikTok the new frontier for fashion reinvention?
item.content:encoded: How a young designer got brought on to help redesign a legacy sports brand following a TikTok post.

item.title: Harry and Meghan visit refugee camp as part of Middle East trip
item.content:encoded: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex's trip to Jordan is their first international tour as a couple since August 2024.

item.title: Bill Gates 'took responsibility' over Epstein ties in staff meeting, foundation says
item.content:encoded: A newspaper reports Gates apologised to staff over his links to Epstein and said: "I did nothing illicit. I saw nothing illicit."

item.title: Taylor to retire after Dublin bout later this year
item.content:encoded: Katie Taylor confirms she will bring the curtain down on her decorated career after a farewell fight in Dublin this summer.

item.title: What should England do about Jos Buttler?
item.content:encoded: What are the options facing England amid Jos Buttler's struggles at the T20 World Cup. Could they really drop their former captain?

item.title: Martin Lewis on what the new energy price cap means
item.content:encoded: Typical household energy bills will fall by 7% in April, regulator Ofgem has announced, following a shake-up in charges by the government.

item.title: Martin Lewis on what the new energy price cap means
item.content:encoded: Typical household energy bills will fall by 7% in April, regulator Ofgem has announced, following a shake-up in charges by the government.

item.title: Chelsea and West Ham fined over 'mass confrontation'
item.content:encoded: Chelsea and West Ham are fined £325,000 and £300,000 respectively for a "mass confrontation" between players in their match in January.

item.title: Not even potholes will hold up self-driving cars, UK firm predicts
item.content:encoded: Wayve says it's confident all cars will one day be autonomous, as it announced more than a £1bn in additional investment.

item.title: Not even potholes will hold up self-driving cars, UK firm predicts
item.content:encoded: Wayve says it's confident all cars will one day be autonomous, as it announced more than a £1bn in additional investment.

item.title: Phil Collins, Pink and Shakira nominated for Rock & Roll Hall of Fame
item.content:encoded: Jeff Buckley, Lauryn Hill, Pink, Shakira and Mariah Carey are also among the 17 nominees this year.

item.title: Man who murdered nine-year-old girl as she played with hula hoop in street jailed
item.content:encoded: Lilia Valutyte, 9, was playing outside a shop in Boston when she was stabbed by Deividas Skebas.

item.title: Tourette's campaigner says BBC 'should have worked harder' to stop his slur being aired
item.content:encoded: John Davidson, who tics due to his condition, shouted a racial slur while two black actors were on stage.

item.title: Gucci criticised for 'AI slop' images ahead of major fashion show
item.content:encoded: Users of social media - where the marketing campaign has been launched - say it is out of keeping with Gucci's reputation for luxury.

item.title: Gucci criticised for 'AI slop' images ahead of major fashion show
item.content:encoded: Users of social media - where the marketing campaign has been launched - say it is out of keeping with Gucci's reputation for luxury.

item.title: Fact-checking Trump's longest ever State of the Union
item.content:encoded: President Donald Trump said the US "is winning again" - making a series of claims about his record in a speech which lasted almost two hours.

item.title: 'Exceptionally rare' Roman lead blocks found on farmland
item.content:encoded: The objects, which were used to produce tools and weapons, were found on grazing land in west Wales.

item.title: Aston Martin cuts 20% of workforce as losses widen
item.content:encoded: About 600 jobs will go at the luxury car maker, which in part blames US tariffs for its troubles.

item.title: New travel rules for UK visitors kick in today - find out how this affects you
item.content:encoded: From 25 February, a new system will come into force which will affect many people, including British dual nationals.

item.title: New travel rules for UK visitors kick in - how are you affected?
item.content:encoded: From 25 February, a new system will come into force which will affect many people, including British dual nationals.

item.title: Why scientists fear Emperor penguins' annual moult may be killing them
item.content:encoded: Each year the birds must stay on floating ice long enough to replace their weather-beaten feathers.

item.title: What is happening to gas and electricity prices?
item.content:encoded: Typical household bills will fall by 7% when the new energy cap takes effect on 1 April 2026.

item.title: 'I'm proud of my heritage' - meet Britain's youngest ever F1 driver
item.content:encoded: Arvid Lindblad tells BBC Sport about being shaped by his Indian and Swedish heritage and how he was fixated on reaching F1 from aged five.

item.title: Will walk-in GP clinics deliver one million extra appointments in Scotland?
item.content:encoded: The first of 16 new walk-in clinics across Scotland is now open but it is not clear when a target of them delivering one million appointments will be hit.

item.title: House prices in Wales rise faster than UK average - see how your area compares
item.content:encoded: Some areas have seen average house prices increase by 7% in the past year, according to ONS data.

item.title: House prices in Wales rise faster than UK average - see how your area compares
item.content:encoded: Some areas have seen average house prices increase by 7% in the past year, according to ONS data.

item.title: Shein's elusive boss hails Chinese roots in rare public appearance
item.content:encoded: His speech follows years of the firm focusing away from China as it moved its headquarters to Singapore.

item.title: Disabled woman, 33, put in nursing home against her will feels 'betrayed'
item.content:encoded: Lucinda Ritchie, who has full mental capacity, was transferred from a hospital bed despite her refusal.

item.title: Paramount boosts Warner Bros offer to rival Netflix in takeover bid
item.content:encoded: Warner Bros says the latest proposal could convince it to abandon the deal it struck with Netflix.

item.title: Snoop Dogg's surreal Swansea visit heralds late drama
item.content:encoded: The difference between Swansea v Preston and other second-tier matches was that one of the Welsh club's co-owners happens to be a hip-hop legend.

item.title: US threatens Anthropic with deadline in dispute on AI safeguards
item.content:encoded: The AI developer laid out red lines on military use of its products, a source said.

item.title: Discord delays age verification plans after user outcry
item.content:encoded: Users were unhappy about plans for age verification to require facial or ID scans.

item.title: Apple says some Mac Mini production will move to the US
item.content:encoded: The technology giant had pledged to increase investment in the US by $600bn, under pressure from Trump.

item.title: Google apologises for Baftas alert to 'see more' on racial slur
item.content:encoded: Google said the news alert was an error that should not have happened.

item.title: Everything you need to know about the new school uniform law
item.content:encoded: New guidelines have been issued by the Department of Education in the wake of law changes on uniforms.

item.title: Reddit fined £14m for 'concerning' child age check failings
item.content:encoded: The UK's data watchdog said the failings meant children could be exposed to harmful material online.

item.title: Reform vows to overhaul pension schemes for new local government workers
item.content:encoded: Reform plans to end more generous defined benefit pension schemes for new local government workers if it wins office.

item.title: A Woman's Hour and SEND in the Spotlight special
item.content:encoded: We hear from a range of voices on the impact of the government's SEND reforms in England.

item.title: Chocolate kept in anti-theft boxes as shops warn it's being stolen to order
item.content:encoded: Retailers and police forces tell the BBC that thieves are targeting chocolate and selling it on.

item.title: Number of workers on zero-hours contracts hits record high ahead of crackdown
item.content:encoded: There has been a 181,000 increase in the number of zero-hours contracts since Labour was elected.

item.title: Trump Organization unveils plan for 'Australia's tallest building'
item.content:encoded: The tower will be built on Queensland's Gold Coast and be 335 metres high, taller than the Shard in London.

item.title: FedEx sues for Trump tariff refund
item.content:encoded: The US Supreme Court ruling that the US president overstepped when imposing levies paved the way for firms to seek a refund.

item.title: Orbital space race heats up in Arctic north
item.content:encoded: Europe lags far behind the US and China in orbital space launches, but new facilities are opening up.

item.title: Company director jailed over £7m airline parts fraud
item.content:encoded: The judge said the actions were a "more or less complete undermining" of rules designed to ensure passenger flights are safe.

item.title: When is the Spring Statement and what might be in it?
item.content:encoded: Chancellor Rachel Reeves will give an update on her plans for the UK economy when she gives a statement alongside an economic forecast on 3 March.

item.title: Are you cut out for living and working in Antarctica?
item.content:encoded: Jobs are available on the icy continent for chefs, plumbers, carpenters and even hairdressers.

item.title: When the retail staff can't help you
item.content:encoded: This customer might be feeling trolled, in this scene from Small Prophets.

item.title: How do you modernise mango farming?
item.content:encoded: India's mango farmers are being urged to innovate as climate change makes cultivation "unpredictable".

item.title: The two farms in Senegal that supply many of the UK's vegetables
item.content:encoded: During winter in Britain fresh produce is sent by cargo ship from the West African nation every week.

item.title: Why youth unemployment is rising
item.content:encoded: Unemployment in the UK rose to its highest rate in nearly five years at the end of 2025

item.content:encoded: What to know about the two firms' blockbuster battle to control Warner Bros Discovery.

item.title: Trump's big, long, State of the Union speech
item.content:encoded: Can the president’s record breaking speech change voters’ minds ahead of the midterms?

item.title: Reddit's human content wins amid the AI flood
item.content:encoded: Reddit says its human contributors are valued amid an internet awash with AI-generated content.

item.title: Trump eyes Venezuela visit – but obstacles to his oil plan remain
item.content:encoded: The US president wants American energy firms to start extracting the crude but they are reluctant.

item.title: The US economy is growing - so where are all the jobs?
item.content:encoded: As hiring rates and job openings drop, some worry a tough job market could be here to stay.

item.title: Get a grip: Robotics firms struggle to develop hands
item.content:encoded: Developing a durable and affordable hand is one of the biggest challenges in robotics.

item.title: Who is billionaire Sir Jim Ratcliffe and how did he make his money?
item.content:encoded: The industrialist and Manchester United co-owner has apologised over comments he made about immigration.

item.title: The Dutch love four-day working weeks, but are they sustainable?
item.content:encoded: The Netherlands has the lowest working hours in Europe, but some say it is harming its economy.

item.title: How £50m 'fish disco' could save farmland
item.content:encoded: Innovative tech scares fish away from nuclear cooling pipes.

item.title: Why food fraud persists, even with improving tech
item.content:encoded: Even with sophisticated technology it is still difficult to detect fake foods.

item.title: The real impact of roadworks on the country - and why they're set to get worse
item.content:encoded: There is a fine balance between the benefits of improved infrastructure, versus the cost of disruption. Does the country have it right?

item.title: Why the railways often seem to be in such chaos over Christmas
item.content:encoded: Parts of Britain’s rail network will close for engineering work over the festive period - but is that the right time to do it?

item.title: Budget 2025: What's the best and worst that could happen for Labour?
item.content:encoded: Three days in, after a tax U-turn and partial climbdown on workers' rights, Laura Kuenssberg looks at what impact Budget week might have.

item.title: Has Britain's budget watchdog become too all-powerful?
item.content:encoded: Ahead of this week's Budget, some have accused the Office for Budget Responsibility of being a "straitjacket on growth"

item.title: The curious case of why Poundland is struggling during a cost-of-living crisis
